DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Source never performed opperations at this site

_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Double shelf couplers, block valves, pressure balancing system, and temperature/pressure gauges
_prev_prog_2.CH_OtherChanges: Initial hazard review using a what-if checklist process was conducted on the transloading process and equipment by Synergy Liquids personnel and the equipment supplier.
_prev_prog_2.Description:
1.0 Prevention Program

The transloading process at Trimac Tulsa Transloading Facility has a NAICS Code of 42471 and is considered a Program 2 level prevention program as described in Subpart D of 40 CFR 68 (68.48 through 68.60). The seven requirements for the prevention program are described below and will be implemented on a daily basis at the facility.



1.1 Safety Information (40 CFR 68.48) 

RMP safety information requirements include compiling written information concerning equipment and processes. Compiled information must address:



?    Materials Safety Data Sheets (MSDS)

?    Maximum inventory

?    Storage and Process limits

?    Equipment Specifications

?    Codes and Standards



Synergy Liquids maintains a current MSDS for RGB and RGP at the facility.



1.2 Hazard Review (40 CFR 68.50)

An initial hazard review using a what-if checklist process was conducted on the transloading process and equipment by Synergy Liquids personnel and the equipment supplier. 



To prevent / control the catastrophic release of RGB and RGP, the following controls are integrated into the transloading process:



?    Double shelf couplers (to prevent tank punctures during car handling)

?    Safety relief valves at rail cars and tank trucks

?    Manual shutoffs at rail cars and tank trucks

?    Block valves

?    Pressure balancing system

?    Temperature and pressure gauges



Synergy Liquids will update hazard review at least once every 5 year or whenever there is a major change in the process.



1.3 Operating Procedures (40 CFR 68.52)

Synergy Liquids operating procedures address the steps for each operating phase, operating limits and safety system, and their functions.



Specific requirements are as follows:



?    Initial start up

?    Normal operations

?    Temporary Operations

?    Emergency Operations

?    Normal Shutdown

?    Start up following a turnaround or emergency shutdown

?    Consequences of deviations

?    Equipment inspections



Transloading process work instructions were developed and were used as the basis for the training. Written copies of work instructions are available at the facility but are not considered controlled documents.  



In addition to the transloading work instruction, the facility operator follows established Synergy Liquids procedures for the inspection of railcars, tank trucks and general health, safety and environmental procedures.  



1.4 Training (40 CFR 68.54)

Transloading operations will be performed by a third-party carrier on behalf of Synergy Liquids.

As required under 40 CFR 68.54, training requirements for new operators at the facility include training on operating procedures and must cover health and safety hazards, emergency operations, and safe work practices applicable to the operator normal job or function. Refresher training will be provided at least every three years. Synergy Liquids will determine that each operator has received and understands the training requirements and keep a record of complete training for each operator with the date of the training and the method used to verify that the operator understand the subject matter.



The training program includes on job instruction with emphasis on safety and health hazards. The materials are maintained at the facility. Verification that the operators understand the materials are accomplished through hands-on demonstrations. 



1.5 Maintenance (40 CFR 68.56)

As required by the regulations, Synergy Liquids implemented a maintenance program that includes the preventative maintenance, inspection and testing of the RGB and RGP transloading unit. The specific required provisions are as follows:



?    Written procedures- Administrative guidance

?    Training

?    Inspection and Testing



Synergy Liquids follows a maintenance program to assure system equipment integrity is maintained.



Facility personnel are responsible for level-1 maintenance on the transfer equipment that includes:



?    Daily visual inspection of the transfer equipment



All maintenance on the transfer equipment is performed by the operator using internal maintenance procedures specified by individual component suppliers.  



1.6 Compliance Audits (40 CFR 68.58)

Synergy Liquids is required to conduct compliance audits at least every 3 years from the date of RMP submission. The audit must include an evaluation of the design and effectiveness of risk management program elements and a field inspection of the safety and health conditions and practices to verify that systems are effectively implemented and operational. The compliance audits will be conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the RGB and RGP transloading process. Synergy Liquids will comply with the following document requirements:



?    Certify the compliance audits

?    Develop a written report of the findings of the audit

?    Determine and document an appropriate response to each of the findings of the audit

?    Document any deficiencies that have been corrected

?    Retain the most recent compliance audits reports

?    Make available to operators



As required, Synergy Liquids will undergo an audit every 3 years. The first audit is scheduled for July 2014 or startup date, whichever comes first. 



1.7 Incident Investigation (40 CFR 68.60)

Incident investigation is the process of identifying the underlying causes of incidents and implementing steps to prevent similar events from occurring. The RMP requires the investigation of each incident that resulted in, or could reasonable have resulted in a catastrophic release of regulated substance, injury or off site impact.



The specific requirements of the incident investigation are as follows:



?    Initiate an investigation promptly, no later than 48 hours after the incident

?    Establish an investigation team with at least one team member knowledgeable in the transloading process

?    Address and resolve the teams finding and recommendations

?    Document resolutions and corrective actions

?    Review the report with affected personnel and contactors where applicable

?    Retain the report for five years



 Summarize the investigation in a report, including:



?    Date of incident

?    Date investigation begin

?    Description of the incident

?    Factors contributing to the incident

?    Root cause of the incident

?    Any recommendations to prevent future incidents



Synergy Liquids established incident investigation procedures for the RGB and RGP transloading process as follows:



1.    The facility maintains an updated comprehensive EAP in accordance with OSHA regulations (29 CFR ?1910.38). All operators are trained on the activation of the EAP and their roles. 

2.    All product releases are reported following the incident reporting procedures list in the EAP.

3.    Upon completion of the emergency phase of the incident, a formalized incident investigation process is initiated using an investigation form.



Synergy Liquids will hold an incident review conference call or on-site investigation meeting within 5 days of any incident with injury, evacuation or off site consequence.  Senior operations personnel will lead this call from Synergy Liquids, the operator and other groups or agencies with significant incident involvement.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0 Executive Summary (?68.155)

Synergy Liquids LLC (Synergy Liquids) is submitting this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for Trimac Tulsa Transloading facility in Tulsa, Oklahoma.



1.1 ?68.155(a): Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Stationary Source

Synergy Liquids is committed to operating and maintaining the Refinery Grade Butane (RGB) and Refinery Grade Propylene (RGP) transloading operations in a safe and responsible manner. A combination of accidental release prevention and emergency action planning will be used to protect the environment and to ensure the safety of the employees as well as the citizens of the surrounding communities.



This Executive Summary provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Synergy Liquids will implement, including:



- A description of the facility and the substances regulated by 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68 that are currently handled on-site in stationary sources above their corresponding threshold quantities;

- An overview of the accidental release prevention programs;

- A five-year accident history for significant accidental releases from processes covered by EPA's RMP rule;

- An overview of the emergency response programs; and

- An overview of improvements at the facility implemented to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting the employees, the public, the environment, and company assets.



1.2 ?68.155(b): Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

Synergy Liquids has executed an agreement to utilize the existing rail spur at the Trimac Tulsa Transloading Facility in 2120 N 161st E Ave, Tulsa, Oklahoma.  The proposed operations will include the transloading of RGB and RGP from railcars to tanker trucks or vice versa.  There are no permanent structures or on-site storage facilities associated with the proposed operations.  RGB and RGP will be transferred between the railcars and tanker truc

ks using two hoses - a liquid and a vapor hose.  Transloading operations will be performed by a third-party carrier on behalf of Synergy Liquids; there will be no permanent Synergy Liquids employees located on-site.   



The RGB is a mixture of pentanes (i.e., i-pentane and n-pentane) and butanes (i.e., i-butane and n-butane). The RGP is a mixture of propylene, propane, and ethane. These chemicals have been identified by the EPA as having the potential to cause significant off-site consequences in the event of substantial accidental releases:



Regulated Flammable Substances:

i-Pentane (CAS Number 78-78-4);

n-Pentane (CAS Number 109-66-0);

i-Butane (CAS Number 75-28-5); 

n-Butane (CAS Number 106-97-8);

Propylene (CAS Number 115-07-1);

Propane (CAS Number 74-98-6); and

Ethane (CAS Number 74-84-0).



The maximum inventory of RGB and RGP for the transloading process at the facility is 150,000 gallons.



1.3 ?68.155(c): Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Synergy Liquids takes a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of flammable substances.  Synergy Liquids has developed a written procedure that lists the conditions and guidelines for safely transloading RGB and RGP from a rail car to a tank truck or vice versa.  This procedure will be followed by the third-party carrier who actually performs the transloading on behalf of Synergy Liquids.  



Both RGB and RGP are liquefied flammable gases transported under pressure.  All ignition sources in the vicinity of the transloading operations will be eliminated prior to executing the transloading procedure. 



1.4 ?68.155(d): Five-Year Accident History

Operation of the Trimac Tulsa Transloading Facility will begin in 2014; therefore, there have been no accidents in the past five years.



1.5 ?68.155(e): Emergency Response Program

Synergy Liquids has coordinated emergency response activities with the Tulsa Fire Department.  In the unlikely event

of an accidental release, the transloading operator will notify other operators in the vicinity, dial 911 to alert the local Fire Department and call the Trimac Transportation Operations Manager to alert the permanent employees of the site to evacuate the area.  Synergy Liquids has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) in accordance with OSHA regulations (29 CFR ?1910.38) and coordinated implementation of the EAP with the Operations Manager of the Trimac Transportation.



1.6 ?68.155(f): Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Synergy Liquids is committed to continuous improvement of the safety program.  Third-party carrier recommendations to improve the safety of the transloading operations are reviewed and implemented if they are judged to be effective in improving safety or reducing accident risk.
